data.text: New Bicycle - PEDALS NOT INCLUDED!

I've noticed a ton of bikes I've priced over the last few days, almost all of them DO NOT come with "Pedals". In small print, "PEDALS NOT INCLUDED". $1500 - $2000 for a bike, just throw some standard ones in there or something. I know it's the norm, but do you see that much? Pedals Not Included?
Yes, most higher-end bikes don't come with pedals from new, and people have their own preference so they keep the pedals for the next bike.
data.author: Daniel Trump

data.text: ğŸ¤”Thanks. I guess since riders throw them out any. Good point.
data.author: Mickey L. Foster

data.text: I too was surprised to find that my $2700 mountain bike didn't come with pedals when I bought it, but luckily I had a spare set of cheap plastic platforms to roll on until I bought a nicer set.
data.author: Daniel Trump

data.text: Iâ€™ll do that.
data.author: Mickey L. Foster

data.text: Not everyone has a spare pair of pedals laying around; bike shops often don't include pedals on high end bikes; If you're buying a bike online to be shipped, pedals for test rides are irrelevant; people have dramatically different desires in pedals (cheap plastic pedals are trash/clutter for me, metal pedals I may use someday, road bikes get three bolt clipless system pedals, utility and offroad bikes get two-bolt). I also think selling a mid to high end bike without a saddle is totally reasonable too. These are parts that are routinely swapped for personal preference.

data.text: my $.01, having an extra set of pedals can make the difference between being able to ride or sit it out! I have and ride mountain bikes, bmx bikes and road bikes and not a single one of them have the same type of pedals. Being at the track and your pedals decided to go south then you need a back up plan. They may not be the best but they will make the difference between paying for a practice Sessionï¿¼ that you canâ€™t even finish?

data.text: Pedals are specialized these days. In the last 25 years I have not bought a bike that came with pedals. Wallmart sells them.
data.author: Harris Hickman

data.text: By my experience most riders who ride higher end bikes use some kind of clipless pedals. And the pedals need to match the cleats on their shoes. So this is an even more personal choice than the saddle which is very often swapped out for a better fitting one almost straight after the purchase. Including a pedal on a higher end bike will in many cases just increase the price of the bike by a very slim margin for an item most swap out.

data.text: True, especially when you're butt will be in the saddle for hours on end.

data.text: Two thoughts: 1) As an experienced road cyclists, I want my own clipless pedals that match my other bikes. Junk pedals are a waste byproduct we donâ€™t need to produce. 2) If you are dealing with a bike shop, everything is negotiable, have them â€œbundleâ€ everything you want/need to ride for one price.

data.text: Try stretching the right shoe. depending on the material it could make it a great fit. Synthetics don't like this as much as natural materials but often respond. Look up shoe stretching if you haven't seen it.

data.text: My right foot is much shorter and wider than my left, unfortunate injury as a kid. I deal with these issues all the time. I have purchased two pairs of ski boots to get one pair for me.

data.text: Low-end bikes or bikes that would typically be used in regular shoes often come with pedals, but any bike where someone would typically use cleats/clip-less pedals does not because there are multiple types of those (e.g., SPD, Look, Speedplay) and people have strong preferences.

data.author: Mickey L. Foster

data.text: I think for high-end bikes (which I'd define as over $1k/Â£1k), most buyers will either already have pedals, or will have a preference for specific pedals. I think having the choice avoids yet another plastic item being thrown in the bin or sitting idly in a box of bits. Conscious consumerism. As said, you could apply the same logic to saddles - they are so individual-specific, why waste materials and pollute the planet with an item you probably will swap out pretty soon, if not immediately?
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: When I worked at a bike shop, if the bike was over $1000 dollars we wouldn't even install the pedals that came with the bike, they went straight to the trash. We encouraged people to bring their pedals and shoes for test rides...

data.text: when I owned my own bike shop, I stashed away every decent used part I could find and carried them around in my truck. That way if I saw someone out in about, especially bike commuters and the homeless, that had a flat or mechanical, I could stop and fix it or at least give them a ride to where they were going. I haven't worked in the industry in years and I still carry around an assortment of tube sizes and the tools needed to change a flat.
